snippet: On Jan. 1, the government began depositing pension and scholarship payments directly into the bank accounts of about 245,000 people — to prevent corrupt officials from diverting the money.
abstract: India's new government program designed to prevent corruption deposits government pension and scholarship payments directly into bank accounts of about 245,000 people;  some officials and economists say program is revolutionary, not only because it intends to curb corruption but also to serve as vehicle for lifting countless millions out of poverty.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 1, the government began depositing pension and scholarship payments directly into the bank accounts of about 245,000 people — to prevent corrupt officials from diverting the money.

headline.seo: India Takes Aim at Poverty With Cash Transfer Program
headline.main: India Aims to Keep Money for Poor Out of Others’ Pockets
headline.print_headline: With Deposits, India Aims to Keep Money for the Poor From Others’ Pockets
